Dead Gods

The Dead Gods were the God creators of Marlien, so called by the Charon because they seem to have at one time entered into their Creation, but then destroyed themselves.

History

The dead gods, which may in fact have been one, singular entity, are thought to have been the primary sculptors of Marlien, and entered into it at the dawn of time. They created the first progenitor race to help them shape their creation during its first aeons, during which the most part of the Planes were divided, and the vast, stony, non-euclidean landscape of The Material Plane were carved out.

Marlien was made highly morphic by the standard of other Creations, and the creators wielded such vast quantities of mana that they could reshape it instantaneously and near-infinite times in pursuit of a perfection they could not achieve from outside of its walls.

This perfection though, proved to be unachievable even which such proximity and precision: the dead gods were too much in disarray, pursuing too many competing goals, leading to a growth of internal conflict which prevented them from ever agreeing on the direction of any iteration. During the final iteration of Marlien, as the first progenitor race continued to toil away,, after umpteenth creation and dissatisfaction with the second progenitor race, the dead gods sat in thought so intense that they were, whether intentionally or not, suddenly torn apart by their own will, releasing such a force of will that has not been seen within Marlien since.

In this event the Marlien Girdle was infused with such a quantity of mana that the resident soul stewards together no longer wield enough mana to tear it down should they decide that the Creation is too hazardous for the resident atman. As a result, they settled in for the long-haul, carving out their own plane, The Halls of the Charon, and creating a legion of charon mortals to help guard the atman.

Dissonance

The dissonance of the dead gods are a personification of their incompatible desires which lead to their indefinite pursuit of perfection, and eventual destruction. It is impossible to define whether the dead gods were one atman or many, nor what the impact of their individuals might have been before their destruction, and so only the dissonance are named.

  • Thechtonon, of Knowledge
  • Hlidera, of Beauty
  • Ubrikant, of Dynamism
  • Betrodum, of Predestination
  • Gelfexinerey, of Magiks
  • Sathlid, of Luck
